ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question related to "Match whole words only"
ResponsesInList.Text: I think you‚Äôre maybe getting confused between the auto-linking functionality and the search functionality. The ‚ÄúMatch whole words only‚Äù tickbox does what it says on the tin. It will link ‚ÄúIce‚Äù as a concept but will not highlight that concept when the word justice is displayed. And it only highlights concepts, not content in the description. With the Glossary auto-link filter, you can choose whether to highlight the first occurrence of the concept, or every occurrence. The search functionality will search all of the glossary for occurrences of the concept word/phrase. It works more like the ‚Äúindex at the back‚Äù in the ‚Äúhow humans actually use a glossary‚Äù example you have given - ie. multiple occurrences will be shown. There is also a tick box under the (Glossary) search box which allows you to also search the full text of the entry (ie. concept and description). The alphabetical index at the top (depending on how you set the Glossary up) allows someone to browse directly to an entry (again, using your example, more of a ‚ÄúI know what I‚Äôm looking for‚Äù). The Global search takes things further and will search multiple contexts for the phrase, not just the glossary. So - are you talking about Global search, the Glossary search, or the auto-link functionality? The ‚Äúmatch whole words only‚Äù tickbox will have no affect on the Global or Glossary search functionality.

I haven't figured out quite how permissions should work, but presumably it would only include results from glossaries you are allowed to actually see. The link itself would appear to anyone who's allowed to add entries in the current glossary. ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, it needs to be xml. And saved from a plain text editor. Not Word. Here's a method. In Moodle create a glossary called "Glossary template". Make a new glossary entry and use field-descriptive dummy text. For example, "Concept" in that field, "Description", etc. Once the entry has been created view the glossary's page and use the "Export entries" link in the upper right. A cache is a collection of duplicate data, where the original data is expensive to fetch or¬† compute (usually in terms of access time) relative to the cache. Future accesses to the data can be made by accessing the cached copy rather than refetching or recomputing the original data, so that the perceived average access time is lower. Caches may mark the cached data as 'stale' when the original data is changed, but this is not always the case. The reason caches work at all is that many access patterns in typical computer applications have locality of reference. There are several sorts of locality, but we mainly mean that often the same data is accessed frequently or with accesses that are close together in time, or that data near to each other are accessed close together in time.
